raw_text:
Labour battle plan 'hides Blair'
 
 The Tories have accused Tony Blair of being "terrified" of scrutiny after Labour unveiled details of how it will fight the next general election.
 
 In a break with tradition, the party will ditch the leader's battle bus and daily press briefings in Westminster. Instead Mr Blair will travel to key cities and marginal seats to deliver the party's message. Labour election chief Alan Milburn denied the party was trying to "hide" the prime minister.
 
 He promised "the most positive and upbeat election campaign Labour has ever run". But Tory co-chairman Liam Fox said Labour's plans showed Mr Blair was "terrified of facing proper scrutiny".
 
 "At a time when the British people are looking for more accountability and openness, this government turns its back on them; abandoning plans to tour the country and scared to face journalists in a press conference - it does rather beg the question, 'What have they got to hide?'" The general election is widely expected next May and all the parties are stepping up their campaign preparations. Mr Milburn said the economy would take centre stage in Labour's campaign in what would be a "watershed" election and the "last stand of the Thatcherites". Mr Milburn said Labour's slogan would be "Britain is working - Don't let the Tories wreck it."
 
 The tone of the campaign, said Mr Milburn, would be more conversational than rhetorical; more spontaneous less scripted; less national more local and less based on issues and more concentrated on people. The approach is particularly designed to appeal to women voters, he said. Mr Milburn brushed aside questions over why the chancellor was not present at the Cabinet meeting to discuss election strategy particularly since such importance was being given to the economy. "I'm not privy to everybody's diary," he said. Mr Brown has headed Labour's preparations for previous polls but Mr Milburn is taking that role this time. In a break with the past, Labour will not hold a daily news conference in London. It will not be a "battle bus" style campaign either, he said.
 
 In previous elections, each party leader has had their own battle bus transporting national newspaper, television and radio reporters to staged campaign events around the country. Mr Milburn said Labour's media effort this time would focus more on local newspapers and broadcasters, with every local radio station given the chance to interview the prime minister. Mr Milburn said there would also be a greater effort to set up face-to-face meetings between ministers and the electorate. Former Downing Street media chief Alastair Campbell is also returning to advise Labour on media strategy and campaigning.
 
 Mr Milburn said no decision had been taken yet over whether David Blunkett would have a prominent role in the election. Liberal Democrat chief executive Lord Rennard suggested Labour was avoiding news conferences in London because it wanted less scrutiny of its record and proposals. "Tony Blair seems to have disappeared from Labour leaflets and broadcasts," he said. "In contrast Charles Kennedy will feature prominently in the Liberal Democrat campaign right across the country."
llama3.2:1b: Labour's general election plan involves Tony Blair traveling to key cities and marginal seats, instead of using a daily press briefings and battle bus as it did before. The party promises to tour the country and engage with voters through more local media efforts and face-to-face meetings with ministers. Labour's campaign will be described as "more conversational" rather than traditional.
llama3.2:3b: Labour unveils plans for next general election, ditching traditional battle bus and press briefings, instead focusing on local cities and marginal seats, with a conversational tone and greater emphasis on people rather than issues.
gemma2:2b: Labour's election strategy includes a shift away from traditional methods, featuring local media focus, fewer press conferences, and less scripted speeches. Tony Blair will travel to key cities, focusing on positive messaging regarding economic stability, while avoiding daily media briefings. The party is preparing for a "watershed" election against the "Thatcherites", emphasizing the impact of the economy, with Alan Milburn as the lead strategist. Labour's approach aims for increased transparency and engagement, particularly with women voters, while  David Blunkett's role remains undecided.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Labour Party is ditching traditional tactics of press briefings and prime ministerial visits to deliver a more grassroots, people-oriented campaign.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Tories accuse Tony Blair of being "terrified" of scrutiny after Labour unveiled details of their election strategy, including ditching the leader's battle bus and daily press briefings in favor of delivering messages to key cities and marginal seats. Prime Minister David Cameron is accused of turning his back on accountability and openness with plans that show he fears facing proper scrutiny, as well as abandoning economy-focused Cabinet meetings.
qwen2.5:3b: The Tories accused Tony Blair of being "terrified" of scrutiny after Labour revealed plans for their election strategy, which includes avoiding traditional methods like leader battle buses and daily press briefings at Westminster. Instead, the party will focus on traveling to key cities and marginal seats to deliver messages. Labour promises a positive campaign led by Prime Minister David Milburn, but this approach has been met with skepticism from the Tories, who believe it hides Blair's true intentions. The election is expected in May 2010, and Labour emphasizes the economy as central to their campaign, promising to appeal to women voters and reduce rhetoric for a more conversational tone. Former media strategist Alastair Campbell is advising on strategy again, and whether David Blunkett will play a significant role remains undecided.
opencoder:1.5b:
The Labour battle plan 'hides Blair' summarizes the key points as follows:

1. The Tories have accused Tony Blair of being "terrified" of scrutiny after Labour unveiled details of how it will fight the next general election.
2. In a break with tradition, the party will ditch the leader's battle bus and daily press briefings in Westminster. Instead Mr Blair will travel to key cities and marginal seats to deliver the party's message.
3. Labour election chief Alan Milburn denied the party was trying to "hide" the prime minister.
4. He promised "the most positive and upbeat election campaign Labour has ever run". But Tory co-chairman Liam Fox said Labour’s plans showed Mr Blair was "terrified of facing proper scrutiny".
5. The general election is widely expected next May and all the parties are stepping up their campaign preparations. Mr Milburn said the economy would take centre stage in Labour’s campaign in what would be a "watershed" election and the “last stand of the Thatcherites”.
6. Mr Milburn said Labour’s slogan would be "Britain is working - Don't let the Tories wreck it."
7. The tone of the campaign, Mr Milburn said, would be more conversational than rhetorical; more spontaneous less scripted; less national more local and less based on issues and more concentrated on people.
8. The approach is particularly designed to appeal to women voters, he said. Mr Milburn brushed aside questions over why the chancellor was not present at the Cabinet meeting to discuss election strategy especially since such importance was being given to the economy. "I'm not privy to everybody's diary," he said.
9. Mr Brown has headed Labour’s preparations for previous polls but Mr Milburn is taking that role this time. In a break with the past, Labour will not hold a daily news conference in London. It will not be a "battle bus" style campaign either, he said.
10. Mr Milburn said no decision had been taken yet over whether David Blunkett would have a prominent role in the election. Liberal Democrats chief executive Lord Rennard suggested Labour was avoiding news conferences in London because it wanted less scrutiny of its record and proposals. "Tony Blair seems to have disappeared from Labour leaflets and broadcasts," he said.
smollm:1.7b: The Labour battle plan 'hides Blair' is a reference to Tony Blair's perceived lack of transparency and accountability within the party, particularly during the 2010 general election campaign. The Labour Party has been accused of hiding behind a veil of secrecy, with many details of their strategy and tactics remaining unclear or unknown to the public. This narrative suggests that Labour is trying to hide the truth about their approach to the election from the public, which could be seen as a form of deception or manipulation.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text concisely. Let me read through it carefully.

The main points are about Tony Blair's reputation among the Labour Party during an election campaign. They accuse him of being "terrified" of scrutiny because they're using a new approach—no daily press briefings and more travel to cities and seats instead of staying in Westminster. The Tories are calling this plan "hides Blair."

I should note that Mr. Milburn, the election chief for Labour, is denying hiding Blair. They promised a positive election campaign but also said the party's message might be "terrified" facing scrutiny.

The general election is coming up soon, and they're preparing more focus on economic issues rather than traditional issues. They emphasize a conversational approach with local support, especially targeting women voters. They mention avoiding media meetings in London by focusing on less publicized topics for the campaign.

I should include all these points to make sure the summary captures everything accurately without getting too detailed.
</think>

The Labour Party has introduced a new campaign strategy that deviates from their usual press briefings and daily news conferences, instead traveling to cities and marginal seats. They claim Blair is "terrified of scrutiny," which the Tories accuse of hiding Blair's true political stance. The campaign focuses on local newspapers and media efforts, with an emphasis on face-to-face meetings with voters, particularly targeting women voters. Blair is expected to make a strong impact in the upcoming general election, where they aim for a positive campaign, but there will be a shift toward economic issues rather than traditional topics.
tinyllama:1.1b: The British general election is widely expected next May, and all parties are preparing for a watershed election centered on economic issues. Labour's election chief Alan Milburn has dismissed claims that the party is hiding Tony Blair in its campaign plans, instead emphasizing a more conversational approach. The party will not have daily news conferences or use a daily battle bus transporting national newspaper, television, and radio reporters to events around the country. Instead, Labour's media strategy will focus on local newspapers and broadcasters, with every local radio station given the chance to interview the prime minister. The election's main emphasis will be on people rather than issues, with a greater effort placed on setting up face-to-face meetings between ministers and electors. Despite this shift in approach, Labour still plans to have an equal presence at Cabinet meetings as they did before.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
To summarize, according to the provided text, Labour is planning to introduce a lesser-known leader's battle bus, daily press briefings, and opt for a more grassroots approach to election campaigning. Key points: - Labour plans new battle bus strategy, which could involve local media, broadcasters, and other stakeholders
- This approach will help the party set up better meetings with voters
- The battle buses will be used for local events only, while news conferences will focus on face-to-face interactions
- The general election is expected to take place next May, and there will be more openness in the campaign compared to previous elections
- Former Downing Street media chief Alastair Campbell is returning to advise Labour on media strategy and campaigning, while Liberal Democrat chief executive Lord Rennard suggests Labour may avoid news conferences in London because it wants less scrutiny of its record and proposals
 Thus, the answer to what the text summarizes is that Labour plans to introduce a lesser-known leader's battle bus for local campaign events and use face-to-face meetings with voters instead of news conferences in London.
phi:2.7b: The Tories accuse Tony Blair of being afraid of scrutiny after Labour reveals their election plan, which involves abandoning his battle bus and press briefings, and traveling to key cities and marginal seats to deliver the party's message. Alan Milburn denies that Labour is hiding the prime minister and promises a positive and upbeat campaign focusing on the economy. The Conservatives argue that this shows Blair's fear of facing journalists in a press conference. However, Labour claims that they will have more accountability and openness than ever before, and their slogan is "Britain is working - Don't let the Tories wreck it." The election is expected to take place next May, with all parties preparing for it. Labour plans to focus on people-to-people contact, local newspapers and broadcasters, and face-to-face meetings between ministers and the electorate. They will not have a daily news conference in London or use a battle bus style campaign. The Liberals claim that this is because Labour wants less scrutiny of its record and proposals, while they feature prominently in their campaign.
orca-mini:3b: The Labour party has announced plans to ditch traditional campaign tactics, such as daily press briefings and the leader's battle bus, in order to avoid scrutiny during the next general election. Instead, Prime Minister Tony Blair will travel to key cities and marginal seats to deliver the party's message, with a focus on local newspapers and broadcasters. Alastair Campbell is also returning to advise Labour on media strategy and campaigning. While the Tories have accused Tony Blair of being "terrified" of scrutiny, Labour election chief Alan Milburn denied this and said the party was focused on setting up face-to-face meetings between ministers and the electorate. No decision has been made yet over whether David Blunkett will have a prominent role in the election.
hermes3:3b: Tony Blair's Labour party plans to hide PM from public scrutiny in next election, according to Tories; Labour to ditch leader's battle bus, daily press briefings and national travel for a more local, conversational approach.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Labour has unveiled a battle plan for the next general election that involves Tony Blair traveling to key cities and marginal seats to deliver the party's message, instead of using traditional methods like the leader's battle bus and daily press briefings. Labour chief Alan Milburn promises "the most positive and upbeat election campaign Labour has ever run," but Tory co-chairman Liam Fox accuses Blair of being "terrified" of scrutiny. The party will focus on the economy, with a slogan of "Britain is working - Don'let the Tories wreck it." Their media effort will be more localized, focusing on local newspapers and broadcasters, with every local radio station given the chance to interview the prime minister. Former Downing Street media chief Alastair Campbell is returning to advise Labour on media strategy and campaigning.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Labour has announced a new election strategy, abandoning the traditional leader's battle bus and daily press briefings in Westminster. Instead, Tony Blair will visit key cities and marginal seats to deliver the party's message. Election chief Alan Milburn denied claims that Labour was trying to "hide" Blair, promising a positive campaign focused on the economy. The Conservatives accused Blair of avoiding scrutiny, with Tory co-chairman Liam Fox questioning what Labour had to hide. Labour's slogan will be "Britain is working - Don't let the Tories wreck it," and the campaign will emphasize local engagement and a conversational tone, particularly targeting women voters. The media strategy will shift towards local newspapers and broadcasters, with more direct interactions between ministers and the public. Former media chief Alastair Campbell is returning to advise on strategy. Liberal Democrats also criticized Labour for avoiding scrutiny, contrasting it with their own approach of prominently featuring leader Charles Kennedy.
stablelm2:1.6b: Labour has revealed details for their upcoming general election campaign, ditching the traditional leader's battle bus and daily press briefings in favor of a more personal approach with travel to key cities and marginal seats. Party election chief Alan Milburn defended hiding Tony Blair from scrutiny, stating Labour will focus on the economy as central to the campaign, aiming to appeal more to women voters. The approach is less scripted and more local-driven than previous elections.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Labour has unveiled its election strategy for the upcoming general election, due in May 2023. Unlike past practices, party leader Tony Blair will not travel with a battle bus or hold daily press conferences in Westminster. Instead, he will visit key cities and marginal constituencies to deliver Labour's message. The campaign will focus on the economy as a "watershed" issue and the "last stand of Thatcherism."

Labour election chief Alan Milburn emphasized a more conversational, local, and less scripted approach, tailored to appeal to women voters. The tone will be less national and issue-focused, prioritizing connection with the electorate. Local radio stations and broadcasters, not just London's, will have interview opportunities with Blair. Ministers will engage in face-to-face meetings with constituents.

Former media advisor Alastair Campbell is joining Labour's media strategy team. No decision has been made regarding David Blunkett's prominence in the campaign, while Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy will feature prominently in their national efforts. Tory co-chairman Liam Fox criticized Labour's plans, suggesting they indicate trepidation about scrutiny, especially as the British people seek greater accountability and openness.
reference: Mr Milburn said the economy would take centre stage in Labour's campaign in what would be a "watershed" election and the "last stand of the Thatcherites".Mr Milburn said no decision had been taken yet over whether David Blunkett would have a prominent role in the election.Mr Milburn said Labour's slogan would be "Britain is working - Don't let the Tories wreck it."Mr Milburn said there would also be a greater effort to set up face-to-face meetings between ministers and the electorate.Mr Milburn said Labour's media effort this time would focus more on local newspapers and broadcasters, with every local radio station given the chance to interview the prime minister.Labour election chief Alan Milburn denied the party was trying to "hide" the prime minister.The tone of the campaign, said Mr Milburn, would be more conversational than rhetorical; more spontaneous less scripted; less national more local and less based on issues and more concentrated on people.But Tory co-chairman Liam Fox said Labour's plans showed Mr Blair was "terrified of facing proper scrutiny".It will not be a "battle bus" style campaign either, he said.Mr Brown has headed Labour's preparations for previous polls but Mr Milburn is taking that role this time.
